thread.title: Brexit news: People across North East invited to put Brexit questions to Theresa May

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Brexit news: People across North East invited to put Brexit questions to Theresa May
text:

As the debate over how we leave the EU reaches a climax, ChronicleLive readers have been invited to quiz Theresa May directly about her proposed withdrawal agreement.
MPs will hold an historic vote on December 11 where they will back or reject her Brexit plan.
And over the next few days, you can submit whatever questions you want to the Prime Minister to answer about her deal.
We will then put a selection of them to the Mrs May - and report back her responses.
Simply email questions to jon.walker@reachplc.com
MPs will hold five days of debate before coming to a decision. Prime Minister Theresa May speaks at a press conference after attending a special session of the European Council over Brexit on November 25, 2018 in Brussels, Belgium
Readers might want to know what the agreement will mean for them - whether that’s the economy and jobs, flights to Europe or house prices.
Other people might want to ask the Prime Minister her views on a second referendum, a so-called ‘people’s vote or what would happen if we leave the EU without any deal at all. Brexit timeline - what happens next
December 4, 5, 6, 7 and 10: MPs will host a 40-hour debate over five days.
December 9: BBC will host a live TV debate involving Prime Minister Theresa May
December 11: MPs will vote on Mrs May's deal in Parliament. If it’s a no, the Government has until January 21 next year to put forward a new plan.
March 29, 2019: The official date Theresa May insists Brexit will happen. It means the prospect of a 'no deal' is very much a possibility.
But this is your opportunity to ask whatever you like.
The Prime Minister said: “My message to readers is a simple one: the Brexit deal we have agreed with the EU will deliver for people in Newcastle and across the whole of the North East.
"It’s a deal we can unite behind, to build a brighter future for our country, and to get on with delivering what people voted for in the referendum. Read More Brexit debate: BBC to host TV debate with Theresa May over her Brexit deal
“The deal means we take back control of our borders, our laws and our money. It will provide the certainty that employers and communities need to succeed, protecting the supply chains that businesses here in the North East rely on.
"And it means we will no longer send vast annual sums of money to the EU, helping us focus on the big issues at home that affect people’s day-to-day lives, such as schools and our NHS. Read More
